head.title: When an Italian Place Moves Upscale

hedline.hl1: When an Italian Place Moves Upscale

block.p: ANOTHER Italian restaurant? Yes, indeed, and when it is as good as Mare e Monte in Greenwich, there's reason to cheer. The newcomer, subtitled "Ristorante Toscano," is on the site of Da Vinci's, an old-fashioned family-style pizza place and has the same ownership. But the sweeping changes are all for the better.

Mare e Monte is stylishly cool looking, with white walls, black trim, mirrors, murals and deep-blue touches in chairs, table aprons and draperies. The smoking and non-smoking sections seem to fluctuate as demand dictates, from the large main dining room to a smaller, cozy room near the bar. Softly lighted at night, the main room is bright, light and cheery by day, with sunshine flooding in from the large front windows.

ANOTHER Italian restaurant? Yes, indeed, and when it is as good as Mare e Monte in Greenwich, there's reason to cheer. The newcomer, subtitled "Ristorante Toscano," is on the site of Da Vinci's, an old-fashioned family-style pizza place and has the same ownership. But the sweeping changes are all for the better.

Mare e Monte is stylishly cool looking, with white walls, black trim, mirrors, murals and deep-blue touches in chairs, table aprons and draperies. The smoking and non-smoking sections seem to fluctuate as demand dictates, from the large main dining room to a smaller, cozy room near the bar. Softly lighted at night, the main room is bright, light and cheery by day, with sunshine flooding in from the large front windows.

The menu, tilting toward the Italian north, is modish as well. While the name Mare e Monte (Sea and Mountain) suggests a menu of seafood and game, the concentration is on pasta and meat, with just a few fish and shellfish dishes. Prices are on the high side in what seems typical of Greenwich.

One of the most appealing entrees can be found listed under appetizers: seafood antipasto platter at $15.95. The diversity and generosity of the warm contents -- a plethora of shrimp, scallops, smoked salmon, calamari, octopus, crab claws, marinated anchovies and mushroom caps, served on a bed of linguine with tomato sauce -- make this appropriate as a main course, or easily shared by two or three as a starter.

An appetite-sparking first course is salad, either misticanza (mixed baby greens lightly dressed), tricolore (arugula, radicchio and endive) or the seductive arugula con i funghi selvaggi (a special of arugula and wild mushrooms).

As for non-salad starters, calamari fritti was just as expected -- greaseless, crisply fried and bountiful. Less satisfying was polenta con salsicce -- two large, thick triangles of mealy polenta in a bland marinara sauce accompanied by two sausages, one of which was dense and blackened.

Entrees fared better, from calamari con fagioli (an expert rendering of fork-tender squid and beans in a succulent white wine sauce with tomato, garlic and a nip of sage) to scaloppine di vitello alla zingara (three exquisite escalopes, layered with prosciutto, in a subtle, well-seasoned Madeira sauce, served with a salty new potato and wood-scented slices of grilled eggplant, mushrooms, squash and fennel).

There is a risotto of the day, and at one lunch it was made with fresh asparagus tips and saffron -- a golden, creamy creation that was superb. Less appealing was ravioloni all' olio di tartufo -- large, round cheese-filled ravioli bathed in butter, truffle oil and a touch of saffron -- delicate but rather boring, with minimal saucing.

The lunch and dinner menus share several dishes but there are differences, notably the inclusion of pizza or focaccia as a noontime option. Pizza quattro stagioni was a medley of mushrooms, bits of artichoke hearts, prosciutto, salty and delicious ripe Gaeta olives and mozzarella, spread generously over the thinnest of pizza crusts.
Focaccia Toscana, brushed with olive oil, tomato, fresh basil and rosemary, had a crust as skinny as that on the pizza.

Actually, the first delight at Mare e Monte was the crusty, triangular rolls, called panini, made on the premises and served oven hot. Dipped in high quality extra-virgin olive oil, the rolls made a delicious preprandial warm-up.

A small, separate menu lists dessert, coffee, liqueurs and digestifs. Three desserts were richly rewarding. The tiramisu was a creamy prize, a blend of textures and flavors. Mascarpone cheesecake was properly light and fluffy with a tantalizing whisper of Triple Sec, while an order of biscotti brought three different types studded with almonds, hazelnuts and aromatic spices.

We spent $62.70 for two, which included three courses each before tax, tip and beverages. A well-priced wine list includes 46 choices, 29 Italian, with a few French and the remainder American, many in the $15 to $30 range.
A mundane beer list sports two Italian choices and Samuel Adams, but little else of interest to the suds aficionado.
Mare e Monte's transformation into a first-class establishment adds another upscale choice to Greenwich's restaurant scene. Mare e Monte
Very Good
235 Greenwich Avenue (corner of East Elm Street), Greenwich. 661-5831.
Atmosphere: A large dining room stylishly decorated in black, white and deep blue, plus a smaller room near the bar.
Service: Cordial, correct, professional.

Recommended dishes: Padellata di cozzi a piacere, calamari fritti, arugula con i funghi selvaggi, misticanza, tricolore, calamari con fagioli, scaloppine di'vitello alla zingara, risotto with asparagus and saffron, seafood antipasto platter, pizza quattro stagioni, focaccia Toscana, tiramisu, biscotti, mascarpone cheesecake.
Price range: Lunch entrees $8.50 to $17.50, dinner entrees $13.50 to $23.50.
Credit cards: American Express, Diners Club, Mastercard and Visa.
Hours: 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. Monday through Friday, 3 to 10 P.M. Monday through Friday, 11:30 A.M. to 11 P.M. Saturday, 11:30 A.M. to 10 P.M. Sunday.
Reservations: Accepted.
Wheelchair accessibility: Ground-level access. DINING OUT
